here uh open the doors for education in 1891 about 120 years ago um it uh was
founded in memory of Leland Jr who was uh Leland and Jane Stanford's only son
he died of typhoid fever when he was 15 years old and so they opened this uh
University in his memory and um they had made a decision very shortly after he
passed that because they wouldn't be able to do anything for their own son
they wanted to be able to use their wealth to help other people's children so that was the inspiration for this uh
for this University um from the time that it opened its door Stanford University was uh very untraditional it

to uh providing a practical education they wanted to produce um uh useful and
um uh cultured citizens so uh that that
differed from a lot of the other universities private universities at that time uh there are seven schools and

sponsored research projects here uh at Stanford and we um have a lot of
initiatives on human health the environment sustainability um and three of our
School of Engineering departments are ranked number one by the national research Council
the School of Engineering specifically it's one of the top engineering schools at top university uh we're located here

worldclass research facilities uh there are again like I had referenced in the
last slide we have 5,000 plus uh you know projects that are here researched
that are that's going on on campus uh and so we have some great Labs with state-of-the-art equipment here um there
is a large alumine Network which hopefully uh many of you will be uh
affiliated with when you guys have finished up your programs here and uh we have been pioneering industry education
for quite a long time I don't know how many of you are aware of this but the Stanford center for professional
development actually started out over 50 years ago uh with huet and Packard and
Fred turn who was the dean of the School of Engineering at that time and they wanted to be able to offer education to
their engineers and their their um their you know leaders to be able to continue
and stay at the top of their at their top of their industry so they were able to facilitate a part-time master's

number of years later they uh were able to to broadcast the classes on a
television network and then about uh 12 years ago now uh we started doing online
education so it's evolved over time but we've been doing uh education for industry for a very long
time so the Stanford center for professional development is really uh we consider ourselves a bridge between the

is the academic uh uh programs which you folks are uh enrolled in participating
in and we also have professional programs as well in topics such as strategic decision and risk management
Advanced project management uh it benchmarking uh entrepreneurship and
Innovation so there are also uh the professional education for folks that

m master's degree in management science and engineering and he did it through the honors Cooperative program which is

you can engage um the first one is through individual courses and we call that the non-degree option and you can
enroll in a course for credit um you can take classes with online delivery and 18
units taken through the non-degree option program can be transferred into a master's degree program should you apply
to the department and are admitted um so participation in the
non-degree option actually the students watch the videos they do all of the same
assignments take the same exams they are they have the same expectation and they earn real Stamford graduate credit so uh
it's a great opportunity for Stu for folks to engage with Stanford content here on campus uh that is happening in
the classroom for students that have a a topic area that is of interest to them
we have graduate certificates which is a focused guided curriculum within the School of Engineering the Departments
that are affiliated with uh our our Center um it's three to five courses and
you leave with a credential uh from Stanford uh that you're certified in that
topic and again those credits roll over into a master's degree program the next level is the honors Cooperative program
which is a master's degree program here at Stanford it's the same master's degree that students take here on campus
when they are residential students this just allows people to take the degree at a part-time um uh part-time basis so
they can maintain their careers while they are taking Stanford classes and earning their
degree uh the one of the benefits about the honors Cooperative program is that you can take the courses online if
you're remote or you can come to campus here and take classes you know sit in the classroom and participate so that's
a that's a great benefit for those of you that are that are pursuing your degree and um the least committed
program in this uh which is just for people that maybe they have a master's already or perhaps a PhD but they just

where you can audit a course you get access to the videos and you can you know watch them 24 hours a seven days a
